snippet: A requirement that banks report potential loan losses immediately after making the loan could lead banks to suspend lending to improve earnings.
abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column questions efficacy of new rule adopted by International Accounting Standards Board requiring banks to report potential loan losses immediately after making loan, on theory that some percentage of loans will inevitably go bad; asserts that regulation could cause banks to simply stop making loans to improve their earnings.
lead_paragraph: A requirement that banks report potential loan losses immediately after making the loan could lead banks to suspend lending to improve earnings.

headline.print_headline: Why a Rule on Loan Losses Could Squeeze Credit
